Along the Rockies (Fig. 3a; blue areas in Fig. 2a,b), there is a cold bias that can be partly explained by the positive precipitation and SM bias (Fig. 2c,d), via exacerbated ET and/or snow albedo cooling effects. The positive precipitation bias over mountain areas is a classical problem in climate models
41 and consistent with the categorization of the region as “atmospherically controlled” in Findell and Eltahir
16 . As for the association of a wet and warm bias (yellow areas in Figs 2 and S6– S9), it is quite rare (3 to 6% of the CONUS, depending on the bias association, as quantified on the right panels of Fig. 2) and found mostly in sporadic areas and for a few models over Midwest (northcentral CONUS). Interestingly, the number of grid cells that are warm and dry (red areas in Fig. 2) is very similar whether using SMOS or CCI SM products. Heterogeneous results for the different models are also obtained in eastern CONUS.
